PropertyPage.LayerDescription: Marine Jurisdictions includes five features that represent offshore boundaries for the Unite States: Exclusive Economic Zone, Contiguous Zone, Territorial Sea, Revenue Sharing Boundary, and State Seaward Boundary. The EEZ and State Seaward Boundary are highlighted in dark grey while the other features are represented in dashed light grey lines.

This data set contains areas designated as undeveloped coastal barriers in accordance with the Coastal Barrier Resources Act to preserve natural resources and reduce federal spending. Areas in tan denote Coastal Barrier Resources System (CBRS) units while features outlined in brown denote otherwise protected areas.
This layer outlines the boundaries for National Marine Sanctuaries. The northeast region contains one sanctuary, the Stellwagen Bank National Marine Sanctuary at the mouth of Massachusetts Bay.

PropertyPage.ViewerLayerTitle: MA Area Under Consideration for Potential Wind Energy Development
PropertyPage.LayerDescription: The Request for Interest will be used by the federal government and the Commonwealth of Massachusetts to gauge specific interest in the commercial development of wind resources. The Massachusetts RFI area was selected through consultation with the Massachusetts Renewable Energy Task Force, an intergovernmental coordination group that includes federal and state agencies, tribal governments, and local entities.

PropertyPage.ViewerLayerTitle: Atlantic OCS Wind Energy Areas - RI Call Area
PropertyPage.LayerDescription: This data set represents the most recent changes for the Wind Development Planning Areas in the Atlantic. Wind Planning Areas in this dataset represent up to six different types of announcements within the U.S. Federal Register that can be used to show the current status of an area that is being considered for Wind Power Development. The Smart from the Start Wind Energy Areas (WEAs) are also represented in this layer. When an area type changes status, it will be replaced entirely by the new area. The types of areas and their descriptions can be found in the Attributes section of the metadata record.
This layer represents the coastal counties of New England and their offshore boundaries.

These block polygons outlined in grey support federal land ownership and mineral resource management. All blocks shown belong to Bureau of Ocean Energy Management, Regulation, and Enforcement (BOEMRE) region A. Block labels are visible at an appropriate scale range for viewing.
This layer represents the coastal states of New England and their offshore boundaries.

This layer shows approved liquefied natural gas sites for the Neptune Deepwater LNG Port and Northeast Gateway Deepwater LNG Port offshore Massachusetts. Layer labels only become apparent at an appropriate scale for viewing.
This layer shows the location of an underwater tidal turbine near Eastport, ME to depict offshore energy development and underwater infrastructure.

Permitted Cape Wind shows locations of 130 wind turbines for the Cape Wind project in Nantucket Sound. Turbines will be 258 feet tall from the water's surface to the center of the blades. This layer only become apparent at a large map scale for appropriate viewing.
This dataset depicts the proposed wind turbine locations associated with the Block Island Wind Farm projected headed by Deepwater Wind.
This dataset depicts the proposed cable transmission system associated with the Block Island Wind Farm projected headed by Deepwater Wind.

The Renewable Energy zone is approximately 2 km wide (landward from state water boundary), and has been selected as the most suitable area for offshore renewable energy development in the Ocean SAMP area.

This dataset shows the general locations of proposed tidal energy sites in the Massachusetts ocean management planning area from relevant Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) preliminary permit applications.
This layer represents the maximum tidal currents experienced in the Massachusetts ocean management planning area during a tidal cycle.

This dataset represents the Statiol Requested Lease Area in Maine's offshore waters. If approved the area will be permitted for the development of offshore floating wind turbine technology by Statoil North America.
This layer represents the ocean energy demonstration sites in Maine state waters for the development of alternative ocean energy.

PropertyPage.ViewerLayerTitle: Northeast Offshore Renewable Energy Innovation Zone
PropertyPage.LayerDescription: This dataset depicts the general proposed location of the renewable energy innovation zone from the Marine Renewable Energy Center (MREC). The specific delineation is currently under review by the Minerals Management Service.
This layer represents the locations of submarine cables.

This layer shows cable areas from NOAA Raster Navigational Charts. Each feature corresponds to just a single chart, and therefore features may not line up exactly with some charts that have a different scale.Layer is only visible at large scale ranges.

This layer shows pipeline areas from NOAA Raster Navigational Charts. Each feature corresponds to just a single chart, and therefore features may not line up exactly with some charts that have a different scale.Layer is only visible at large scale ranges.
This layer represents energy related facilities taken from the Environmental Protection Agency’s Facility Registry System.

This layer represents facilities, sites, or places subject to environmental regulation by or of environmental interest to improve public health and the environment. Layer only becomes apparent at a large map scale for appropriate viewing.

The term disposal site means a finally approved and precise geographical area within which ocean dumping of wastes is permitted under conditions specified in permits issued under sections 102 and 103 of the Act. Such sites are identified by boundaries established by coordinates of latitude and longitude for each corner, or by coordinates of latitude and longitude for the center point and a radius in nautical miles from that point. Boundary coordinates shall be identified as precisely as is warranted by the accuracy with which the site can be located with existing navigational aids or by the implantation of transponders, buoys or other means of marking the site.
Wrecks and Obstructions represents marine infrastructure that is necessary for navigation and transportation. Layer only becomes apparent at a large map scale for appropriate viewing.
Aids To Navigation represents marine infrastructure that is necessary for navigation and transportation. Layers only become apparent at a large map scale for appropriate viewing.

Unexploded ordnance (or UXOs/UXBs, sometimes identified as UO) are explosive weapons (bombs, bullets, shells, grenades, land mines, naval mines, etc.) that did not explode when they were employed and still pose a risk of detonation, potentially many decades after they were used or discarded.

Unexploded ordnance (or UXOs/UXBs, sometimes identified as UO) are explosive weapons (bombs, bullets, shells, grenades, land mines, naval mines, etc.) that did not explode when they were employed and still pose a risk of detonation, potentially many decades after they were used or discarded.
Pilot boarding areas are locations at sea where pilots familiar with local waters board incoming vessels to navigate their passage to a destination port.

The areas described are designated as special anchorage areas for purposes of 33 U.S.C. §§2030(g) and 2035(j). Vessels of less than 20 meters in length, and barges, canal boats, scows, or other nondescript craft, are not required to sound signals required by rule 35 of the Inland Navigation Rules (33 U.S.C. 2035). Vessels of less than 20 meters are not required to exhibit anchor lights or shapes required by rule 30 of the Inland Navigation Rules (33 U.S.C. 2030). The anchorage grounds for vessels described in Subpart B of this part are established, and the rules and regulations in relation thereto adopted, pursuant to the authority contained in section 7 of the act of March 4, 1915, as amended (38 Stat. 1053; 33 U.S.C. 471).

This layer desingates shipping safety fairways, traffic separation zones, traffic lanes, precautonary areas, and recommended routes for marine shipping.Data from the U.S. Coast Guard, Electronic Code of Federal Regulations, and the Raster Nautical Charts from NOAA Office of Coast Survey were used to produce this data layer
These are areas within Narragansett Bay that are defined as Restricted Areas by the U.S. Navy.
This layer identifies areas where vessel access is limited or restricted, or within which special regulations apply.
The Code of Federal Regulations designates a mandatory ship reporting system in the northeastern U.S. named WHALESNORTH to protect North Atlantic Right Whales.

The Code of Federal Regulations designates areas that have required speed restriction to protect North Atlantic Right Whales. Vessels are required to travel at a speed of 10 knots or less over ground in these areas.
This layer depicts the concentration of vessel traffic within U.S. waters. Data values are in standard deviations and displayed on a scale from high (red) to low (blue) vessel density.

This layer depicts current working marine aquaculture facilities drawing on the best available information from Maine, New Hampshire, Rhode Island, and Connecticut State aquaculture coordinators and programs.

This layer denotes areas where shellfish harvesting is approved, restricted, or prohibited on a permanent or temporary basis.Data sources are the NH Department of Environmental Services, MA Divison of Marine Fisheries, RI Department of Environmental Management, NYSDEC Bureau of Marine Resources, Connecticut Department of Environmental Protection, and Maine Department of Marine Resources.

This layer represents the amount of fishing effort that has occurred in each ten minute square. Fishing effort is based on the average annual number of reported trips between 2000 and 2009 from the Vessel Trip Report database. This figure does not include effort information for vessels that hold only a federal lobster permit or a surf clam / ocean quahog limited entry permit. Color breaks are based on log transformed and then normalized fishing effort values. The numbers in the legend are actual data values that correspond to an appropriate standard deviation threshold. Intervals are based on the following breakdowns:Way below average: less than -2 standard deviationsBelow average: between -1 and -2 standard deviationsAverage: between -1 and 1 standard deviationsAbove average: between 1 and 2 standard deviationsWay above average: greater than 2 standard deviations

This layer represents the amount of fishing effort that has occurred in each ten minute square using bottom trawls. Fishing effort is based on the average annual number of reported trips between 2000 and 2009 from the Vessel Trip Report database. The bottom trawl category includes beam otter trawls, Danish seines, Scottish seines, bottom otter trawls, and paired otter bottom trawls.Color breaks are based on log transformed and then normalized fishing effort values. The numbers in the legend are actual data values that correspond to an appropriate standard deviation threshold. Intervals are based on the following breakdowns:Way below average: less than -2 standard deviationsBelow average: between -1 and -2 standard deviationsAverage: between -1 and 1 standard deviationsAbove average: between 1 and 2 standard deviationsWay above average: greater than 2 standard deviations

This layer represents the amount of fishing effort that has occurred in each ten minute square using gill nets. Fishing effort is based on the average annual number of reported trips between 2000 and 2009 from the Vessel Trip Report database. Gill net gear includes the floating anchor, runaround, sink anchor, and sink drift gill net types. Color breaks are based on log transformed and then normalized fishing effort values. The numbers in the legend are actual data values that correspond to an appropriate standard deviation threshold. Intervals are based on the following breakdowns:Way below average: less than -2 standard deviationsBelow average: between -1 and -2 standard deviationsAverage: between -1 and 1 standard deviationsAbove average: between 1 and 2 standard deviationsWay above average: greater than 2 standard deviations

This layer represents the amount of fishing effort that has occurred in each ten minute square using long lines. Fishing effort is based on the average annual number of reported trips between 2000 and 2009 from the Vessel Trip Report database. The long line gear category includes bottom, midwater, and surface long line types. Color breaks are based on log transformed and then normalized fishing effort values. The numbers in the legend are actual data values that correspond to an appropriate standard deviation threshold. Intervals are based on the following breakdowns:Way below average: less than -2 standard deviationsBelow average: between -1 and -2 standard deviationsAverage: between -1 and 1 standard deviationsAbove average: between 1 and 2 standard deviationsWay above average: greater than 2 standard deviations

This layer represents the amount of fishing effort that has occurred in each ten minute square using midwater trawls. Fishing effort is based on the average annual number of reported trips between 2000 and 2009 from the Vessel Trip Report database. Midwater trawl gear includes paired and unpaired midwater otter trawls. Color breaks are based on log transformed and then normalized fishing effort values. The numbers in the legend are actual data values that correspond to an appropriate standard deviation threshold. Intervals are based on the following breakdowns:Way below average: less than -2 standard deviationsBelow average: between -1 and -2 standard deviationsAverage: between -1 and 1 standard deviationsAbove average: between 1 and 2 standard deviationsWay above average: greater than 2 standard deviations

This layer represents the amount of fishing effort that has occurred in each ten minute square using non scallop and non surfclam dredges. Fishing effort is based on the average annual number of reported trips between 2000 and 2009 from the Vessel Trip Report database. Mussel dredges, urchin dredges, and other unclassified dredges are included in this category. This dataset does not include values for surfclam / ocean quahog dredges or scallop dredges. Data for surfclam / ocean quahog effort is being compiled and will be added when completed. Color breaks are based on log transformed and then normalized fishing effort values. The numbers in the legend are actual data values that correspond to an appropriate standard deviation threshold. Intervals are based on the following breakdowns:Way below average: less than -2 standard deviationsBelow average: between -1 and -2 standard deviationsAverage: between -1 and 1 standard deviationsAbove average: between 1 and 2 standard deviationsWay above average: greater than 2 standard deviations

This layer represents the amount of fishing effort that has occurred in each ten minute square using other gear types. Fishing effort is based on the average annual number of reported trips between 2000 and 2009 from the Vessel Trip Report database. This gear type includes a variety of fishing gears that are not included in the other gear categories. The other gears category includes all the various kinds of hand gear, cast nets, all of the various kinds of dive gear, fyke nets, mixed gear types, purse seines, stop seines, weirs, and all of the other gear types that do not have a specific gear code. This dataset does not include fishing effort information for scallop dredges, surfclam / ocean quahog dredges, or vessels holding only a federal lobster permit. Color breaks are based on log transformed and then normalized fishing effort values. The numbers in the legend are actual data values that correspond to an appropriate standard deviation threshold. Intervals are based on the following breakdowns:Way below average: less than -2 standard deviationsBelow average: between -1 and -2 standard deviationsAverage: between -1 and 1 standard deviationsAbove average: between 1 and 2 standard deviationsWay above average: greater than 2 standard deviations

This layer represents the amount of fishing effort that has occurred in each ten minute square using pots or traps. Fishing effort is based on the average annual number of reported trips between 2000 and 2009 from the Vessel Trip Report database. This dataset does not include effort information for vessels that hold only a federal lobster permit.Color breaks are based on log transformed and then normalized fishing effort values. The numbers in the legend are actual data values that correspond to an appropriate standard deviation threshold. Intervals are based on the following breakdowns:Way below average: less than -2 standard deviationsBelow average: between -1 and -2 standard deviationsAverage: between -1 and 1 standard deviationsAbove average: between 1 and 2 standard deviationsWay above average: greater than 2 standard deviations

This layer represents vessel traffic density over a period of 2004-2008 based on Vessel Monitoring System (VMS) transponders in 250 meters grid cells. Low density regions are displayed in light colors while heavy density (exceeding 250 boats per grid cell) is displayed in dark blue. This layer is not visible when zoomed beyond a large scale range due to privacy concerns.

This layer shows number of trips from 2000-2009 in ten-minute squares by federally permitted party and charter fishing vessels, based on Vessel Trip Report (VTR) data. Data were log transformed and the class intervals are based standard deviations above or below the mean.This product was created by the Nature Conservancy based on data provided by the National Marine Fisheries Service. This data layer is not downloadable from the Data Extract tool.

This layer was created based on results of the 2012 Northeast Recreational Boater Survey conducted by SeaPlan and the Northeast Regional Ocean Council (NROC). Data values are in standard deviations and displayed on a scale from high (red) to low (green).

Bird Nest Sites contain information on coastal nest sites for bird species. Each point feature is outlined in white and colors aim to match the Bird Habitat layer. Multiple records may be available at the same feature location. Layer only become apparent at a large map scale for appropriate viewing.

This layer contains information on coastal habitat for bird species. Multiple records may be available at the same feature location. Color symbology aims to match the bird types for the Bird Nest Sites layer.
This layer displays offshore marine mammal habitat for dolphins Multiple records may be available at the same feature location.
This layer displays the offshore habitat for pinnipeds. Multiple records may be available at the same feature location.
This layer displays offshore whale habitat. Multiple records may be available at the same feature location.

This layer shows critical habitat locations of the Northern Right whale. Two areas are presented offshore Cape Cod.Data are produced by the Department of Commerce, NOAA National Ocean Service (NOS) and Coastal Services Center (CSC).

This layer represents Sightings Per Unit Effort (SPUE) in ten minute squares for Fin whales in the Northwest Atlantic Marine Ecoregion during winter.Data are presented in 10 minute squares in increments of 0 - 1, 1 - 10, 10 - 100, 100 - 1000, and greater than 1000.Data are compiled by TNC based on seasonal effort ten minute square grids and Cetacean sightings that were created by the U.S. Navy.

This layer represents Sightings Per Unit Effort (SPUE) in ten minute squares for Fin whales in the Northwest Atlantic Marine Ecoregion during spring.Data are presented in 10 minute squares in increments of 0 - 1, 1 - 10, 10 - 100, 100 - 1000, and greater than 1000.Data are compiled by TNC based on seasonal effort ten minute square grids and Cetacean sightings that were created by the U.S. Navy.

Data are presented in 10 minute squares in increments of 0 - 1, 1 - 10, 10 - 100, 100 - 1000, and greater than 1000.Data are compiled by TNC based on seasonal effort ten minute square grids and Cetacean sightings that were created by the U.S. Navy.

This dataset depicts fall sightings per unit effort (SPUE) for the leatherback sea turtle. This dataset was provided courtesy of The Nature Conservancy’s Northwest Atlantic Marine Ecoregional Assessment.

This dataset depicts spring sightings per unit effort (SPUE) for the leatherback sea turtle. This dataset was provided courtesy of The Nature Conservancy’s Northwest Atlantic Marine Ecoregional Assessment.

This dataset depicts summer sightings per unit effort (SPUE) for the leatherback sea turtle. This dataset was provided courtesy of The Nature Conservancy’s Northwest Atlantic Marine Ecoregional Assessment.

This dataset depicts winter sightings per unit effort (SPUE) for the leatherback sea turtle. This dataset was provided courtesy of The Nature Conservancy’s Northwest Atlantic Marine Ecoregional Assessment.

This dataset depicts fall sightings per unit effort (SPUE) for the loggerhead sea turtle. This dataset was provided courtesy of The Nature Conservancy’s Northwest Atlantic Marine Ecoregional Assessment.

This dataset depicts spring sightings per unit effort (SPUE) for the loggerhead sea turtle. This dataset was provided courtesy of The Nature Conservancy’s Northwest Atlantic Marine Ecoregional Assessment.

This dataset depicts summer sightings per unit effort (SPUE) for the loggerhead sea turtle. This dataset was provided courtesy of The Nature Conservancy’s Northwest Atlantic Marine Ecoregional Assessment.

This dataset depicts winter sightings per unit effort (SPUE) for the loggerhead sea turtle. This dataset was provided courtesy of The Nature Conservancy’s Northwest Atlantic Marine Ecoregional Assessment.

This layer represents shellfish habitat for Maine and Massachusetts. Areas offshore Massachusetts include habitat where the species has been observed since the 1970’s, while Maine habitat areas are represent habitat observed in the 2005-2007 tow surveys. Species include blue mussel, bay scallop, European oyster, American oyster, Atlantic surf clam, quahog, sea scallop, surf clam, ocean quahog, razor clam, and soft-shell clam.

PropertyPage.ViewerLayerTitle: Habitat Areas of Particular Concern - HAPC
PropertyPage.LayerDescription: Habitat Areas of Particular Concern

PropertyPage.ViewerLayerTitle: Essential Fish Habitat - Areas Protected from Fishing
PropertyPage.LayerDescription: Designated EFH areas where fishing or the use of fishing gears has been restricted or modified in order to minimize the adverse effects of fishing on EFH, as required by Section 303(a)(7) of the Magnuson Stevens Act.

This layer represents weighted persistence in each ten-minute square for Atlantic Cod during the fall season. The weighted persistence metric identifies where this species has consistently been found over time in high abundance. Data are compiled by TNC based on National Marine Fisheries Service's bottom trawl surveys from 1970 to 2006.

This layer represents weighted persistence in each ten-minute square for Atlantic Cod during the spring season. The weighted persistence metric identifies where this species has consistently been found over time in high abundance. Data are compiled by TNC based on National Marine Fisheries Service's bottom trawl surveys from 1970 to 2006.

This layer represents weighted persistence in each ten-minute square for Atlantic Herring during the fall season. The weighted persistence metric identifies where this species has consistently been found over time in high abundance. Data are compiled by TNC based on National Marine Fisheries Service's bottom trawl surveys from 1970 to 2006.

This layer represents weighted persistence in each ten-minute square for Atlantic Herring during the spring season. The weighted persistence metric identifies where this species has consistently been found over time in high abundance. Data are compiled by TNC based on National Marine Fisheries Service's bottom trawl surveys from 1970 to 2006.

Atlantic herring is a fish forage species, which are potential prey to many ocean predators. This layer shows sand lance abundance using graduated symbols, where data intervals indicate count of species.

Atlantic mackerel is a fish forage species, which are potential prey to many ocean predators. This layer shows Atlantic herring abundance using graduated symbols, where data intervals indicate count of species.

Sand lance is a fish forage species, which are potential prey to many ocean predators. This layer shows Atlantic mackerel abundance using graduated symbols, where data intervals indicate count of species.
This dataset shows species richness based on fall bottom trawl surveys from 2009-2011. Where dark blue areas indicate low species richness and dark red areas indicate high species richness.
This dataset shows total fish biomass based on fall bottom trawl surveys from 2007-2011. Values are kg, where dark blue areas indicate low biomass and dark red areas indicate high biomass.
This dataset shows total fish biomass based on fall bottom trawl surveys from 2007-2011. Values are kg, where dark blue areas indicate low biomass and dark red areas indicate high biomass.

This dataset depicts the log of abundance values for Calanus finmarchicus during the fall based on data from 2003-2007. Where dark blue areas indicate low abundance and dark red areas indicate high abundance.
This dataset depicts the log of abundance values for Euphausiids during the fall based on data from 2003-2007. Where dark blue areas indicate low abundance and dark red areas indicate high abundance.

This dataset depicts the log of abundance values for Gammarid amphipods during the fall based on data from 2003-2007. Where dark blue areas indicate low abundance and dark red areas indicate high abundance.

This dataset depicts the log of abundance values for Mysid shrimp during the fall based on data from 2003-2007. Where dark blue areas indicate low abundance and dark red areas indicate high abundance.

This dataset depicts average fall phytoplankton concentrations (chlorophyll a) with units in mg/m3.This dataset was provided courtesy of The Nature Conservancy’s Northwest Atlantic Marine Ecoregional Assessment.

This dataset depicts average spring phytoplankton concentrations (chlorophyll a) with units in mg/m3.This dataset was provided courtesy of The Nature Conservancy’s Northwest Atlantic Marine Ecoregional Assessment.

This dataset depicts average summer phytoplankton concentrations (chlorophyll a) with units in mg/m3.This dataset was provided courtesy of The Nature Conservancy’s Northwest Atlantic Marine Ecoregional Assessment.

This dataset depicts average winter phytoplankton concentrations (chlorophyll a) with units in mg/m3.This dataset was provided courtesy of The Nature Conservancy’s Northwest Atlantic Marine Ecoregional Assessment.

This layer represents coastal eelgrass habitat for Connecticut, Rhode Island, Massachusetts, New Hampshire, and Maine. Due to the nature of the merged dataset and discrepancies in state collection programs, not all records contain data for each field.
This layer depicts wetlands greater than 10 acres in coastal counties for the northeast.

The Nature Conservancy (TNC) has developed a model to predict the location of potential benthic habitats and the species that they likely contain. This layer represents the results of that model with each color indicating an individual benthic habitat. This dataset is intended for use at the regional scale and may not be adequate for site specific decisions. Users should refer to the attached metadata and Chapter Three of the Northwest Atlantic Marine Ecoregional Assessment to better understand the methods, constraints and suggested uses of this information. Chapter Three can be viewed here.Benthic habitats are unique combinations of ecological marine units and their corresponding species assemblages, or groups of benthic species that are commonly found together. Ecological Marine Units or EMUs are unique combinations of physical characteristics (i.e. depth, sediment grain size, and seabed forms). Each of these physical characteristics is grouped according to thresholds established by significant statistical relationships to the species assemblages. The species assemblages are defined using data from benthic grab samples provided by the Northeast Fisheries Science Center, National Marine Fisheries Service. Depth is based on the 1998 Coastal Relief Model created by NOAA/NGDC that has been augmented with data from the NOS Bathymetric and Fish Maps and the USGS Gulf of Maine 15’ Bathymetry. The sediment grain size data is interpolated from a point dataset from USGS’s usSEABED. Seabed forms are comprised of the two-way combination of land position index and degree of slope. Both of these values are calculated based on the augmented Coastal Relief Model dataset. Additional information on each analysis can be found in Chapter Three of the Northwest Atlantic Marine Ecoregional Assessment.

This dataset provides information on the Northeastern Regional Association of Coastal Ocean Observing Systems (NERACOOS) buoys and monitoring stations. NERACOOS is the Northeastern Regional Association of Coastal Ocean Observing Systems and is a component of the national Integrated Ocean Observing Sysem (IOOS).
This layer represents the locations of the National Water Information System monitoring locations.

This layer represents predicted tide ranges for 2010. The size of the circles are based on the mean tide level for each location. This dataset is based on the 2010 tide predictions from the NOAA Center for Operational Oceanographic Products and Services.

PropertyPage.ViewerLayerTitle: Maximum Tidal Currents Speed m/s, January 2009
PropertyPage.LayerDescription: This layer represents maximum tidal current speed in meters per second. The data is derived from the 33 year long hindcast by the University of Massachusetts Dartmouth SMAST lab using their unstructured FVCOM hydrodynamic model. This data represents a sample for January 2009 and is for demonstration purposes.

PropertyPage.ViewerLayerTitle: Annual Mean Offshore Wind Speed m/s
PropertyPage.LayerDescription: This layer shows modeled offshore wind speed in meters per second at a 90 meter hub height in 100 meter grid cells. The minimum is 5.5 m/s and the maximum is 10.375 m/s.

This bathymetric dataset represents 10 meter depth contours from near-shore regions to the continental shelf, and 100 meter depth contours beyond the 200 meter shelf edge. All contour lines are represented in light blue.
This layer provides classified shoreline types for the coastal northeast from Connecticut to New Hampshire. Layer only become apparent at a large map scale for appropriate viewing.

This layer shows sediment grain size distributions. This data layer is supplied primarily as a gross overview and to show general textural trends. The sediment classification for any given area reflects the dominant surficial sediment type for that polygon. Layer is only apparent at small map scales for appropriate viewing.

This layer represents bathymetry in 90 meter square grid cells for offshore New England to the continental shelf. Darker blue denotes deeper bathymetry values. The greatest depth is 3942.5 meters below sea level. This layer also includes elevation above sea level for some land features, however these areas are set as invisible to emphasize offshore bathymetry.

This layer represents the seabed forms that were created as part of TNC's Northwest Atlantic Marine Ecoregional Assessment. Seabed forms are the combination of slope and a land position index value. Additional details on how the seabed forms where created can be found in Chapter Three of the Northwest Atlantic Ecoregional Assessment, which can be found here.
This layer shows population for 2010 by state. Its is based on the 2010 Census.
This layer shows population for 2010 by county. Its is based on the 2010 Census.

This layer shows total employment for coastal counties in 2010 for all ocean sectors in natural break intervals that designate low, medium, and high values. Ocean sectors include marine construction, living resources, offshore mineral extraction, ship and boat building, tourism and recreation, and marine transportation.It was produced from the 2010 Census and the Economics: National Ocean Watch (ENOW) tabular data from NOAA Coastal Services Center.

This layer shows total establishments for coastal counties in 2010 for all ocean sectors in natural break intervals that designate low, medium, and high values. Ocean sectors include marine construction, living resources, offshore mineral extraction, ship and boat building, tourism and recreation, and marine transportation.It was produced from the 2010 Census and the Economics: National Ocean Watch (ENOW) tabular data from NOAA Coastal Services Center.

This layer shows total wages for coastal counties in 2010 for all ocean sectors in natural break intervals that designate low, medium, and high values. Ocean sectors include marine construction, living resources, offshore mineral extraction, ship and boat building, tourism and recreation, and marine transportation.It was produced from the 2010 Census and the Economics: National Ocean Watch (ENOW) tabular data from NOAA Coastal Services Center.

This layer shows total GDP for coastal counties in 2010 for all ocean sectors in natural break intervals that designate low, medium, and high values. Ocean sectors include marine construction, living resources, offshore mineral extraction, ship and boat building, tourism and recreation, and marine transportation.It was produced from the 2010 Census and the Economics: National Ocean Watch (ENOW) tabular data from NOAA Coastal Services Center.

This layer shows total Real GDP for coastal counties in 2010 for all ocean sectors in natural break intervals that designate low, medium, and high values. Ocean sectors include marine construction, living resources, offshore mineral extraction, ship and boat building, tourism and recreation, and marine transportation.It was produced from the 2010 Census and the Economics: National Ocean Watch (ENOW) tabular data from NOAA Coastal Services Center.
This layer shows labels of coastal hydrological features such as bays, channels, bars, and beaches. Labels only become apparent at a large map scale for appropriate viewing.

This layer serves as a reference bounding box for most of the data layers in the Northeast Ocean Data Viewer. It does not represent any geographic boundaries or political jurisdictions and is purely for the purpose of containing data layers to the general northeast region.Top: 46° Bottom: 37° Left: -74° Right: -65°This dataset was developed by NOAA Costal Services Center.
This layer represents longitude and latitude every 10 degrees within the Northeast Portal Data Extent layer.This dataset was developed by NOAA Costal Services Center.
This layer represents longitude and latitude every 5 degrees within the Northeast Portal Data Extent layer.This dataset was developed by NOAA Costal Services Center.
This layer represents longitude and latitude every 1 degree within the Northeast Portal Data Extent layer.This dataset was developed by NOAA Coastal Services Center.
This layer represents longitude and latitude every 15 minutes within the Northeast Portal Data Extent layer.This dataset was developed by NOAA Costal Services Center.
